L19: In 2013 all Pepco MD residential customers with activated AMI meters were placed on the PESC rate. In Delmarva Power DE PESC was made available to 6800 customers with activated AMI meters beginning in the summer of 2012 and the program was fully deployed to all Standard Offering Service (SOS) customers with activated AMI meters during the summer of 2013. In Delmarva Power MD beginning in the summer of 2014 a limited number of residential customers with activated AMI meters were placed on PESC DP rate. Enrollment was subsequently expanded jurisdiction- wide in 2015. The PESC program has not been approved in the District of Columbia for Pepco DC customers. Due to the lack of AMI in ACE’s service territory the PESC program is not currently available.    The PESC Program provides a residential customer bill credit of $1.25 per kWh reduced during PESC event periods.

L29: model each feeder in its power flow analysis software. From this analysis predicted system violations such as low voltage and thermal overloads are identified and resolved through the system recommendations process.    System Recommendations Process   Upon completing its analysis process PHI considers the specific predicted system violations to develop recommended actions which may consist of:    1) Operational measures – Resetting relay limits conducting phase balancing or other measures 2) Load transfers – Conducting field switching to transfer load from a higher loaded feeder to a lower loaded feeder 3) Short-range construction projects - Feeder extensions installation of capacitors or voltage regulators reconductoring 4) Long-range construction projects - New feeder extensions new substation transformers or entirely new substations   Once the recommended actions are identified an area plan containing construction recommendations is issued. From this analysis predicted system violations such as low voltage and thermal overloads are identified and resolved through the system recommendations process.    System Recommendations Process   Upon completing its analysis process PHI considers the specific predicted system violations to develop recommended actions which may consist of:    1) Operational measures – Resetting relay limits conducting phase balancing or other measures 2) Load transfers – Conducting field switching to transfer load from a higher loaded feeder to a lower loaded feeder 3) Short-range construction projects - Feeder extensions installation of capacitors or voltage regulators reconductoring 4) Long-range construction projects - New feeder extensions new substation transformers or entirely new substations   Once the recommended actions are identified an area plan containing construction recommendations is issued. L19: In 2013 all Pepco MD residential customers with activated AMI meters were placed on the PESC rate. In Delmarva Power DE PESC was made available to 6800 customers with activated AMI meters beginning in the summer of 2012 and the program was fully deployed to all Standard Offering Service (SOS) customers with activated AMI meters during the summer of 2013. In Delmarva Power MD beginning in the summer of 2014 a limited number of residential customers with activated AMI meters were placed on PESC DP rate. Enrollment was subsequently expanded jurisdiction- wide in 2015. The PESC program has not been approved in the District of Columbia for Pepco DC customers. Due to the lack of AMI in ACE’s service territory the PESC program is not currently available.    The PESC Program provides a residential customer bill credit of $1.25 per kWh reduced during PESC event periods.

L255: 
L256: Overview of Revised Technical Analysis
L257: 
L258: 
L259:  PHI’s criteria limits are designed to identify the potential for detrimental
L260: technical conditions that impact the power quality at the customer level
L261: and/or the reliability of the distribution system: 
L262:  High- and low-voltage conditions
L263:  Voltage fluctuations
L264:  Frequency deviations
L265:  Harmonic distortions
L266:  Overcurrent (Overload & Excessive Fault Current) 
L267:  Excessive impacts on the reliable service life of regulating equipment
L268:  Reactive power issues – power factor variations
L269:  Reverse power flow on equipment not designed for it
L270:  Protection and coordination issues
L271:  Impacts on the transmission system
L272:  Impacts on other customers 
L273: 
L274:

L276: 
L277: Levels of Engineering Review of Interconnection
L278: Applications
L279: 
L280: 
L281: Small Application
L282: Review 
L283: 
L284: 
L285: Pre-screen 
L286: 
L287: 
L288: Screen
L289: 
L290: 
L291: Advanced Study 
L292: 
L293: 
L294: •  PHI utilizes a hierarchal
L295: screening process
L296: •  An application will require
L297: more thorough and
L298: comprehensive analysis only
L299: if it fails to pass a simpler
L300: screen first. 
L301: •  Process is consistent with the
L302: FERC Small Generator
L303: Interconnection Procedures
L304: (SGIP) 
L305: 
L306: 
L307: 9 
L308: February 1 2016
L309: 
L310: Small System Application Review (50kW and below) 
L311: 
L312: 
L313:  An expedited process for systems 10 kW and below has 
L314: significantly improved response time and that process will be
L315: extended to 25 kW systems starting in September 2016
L316:  Applications 25kW and below qualify for expedited review if they
L317: meet the following conditions: 
L318: •  Not currently served by a restricted or network feeder
L319: •  Inverter is IEEE/UL certified
L320: •  Total kW of PV Array(s) does not exceed the transformer rating
L321: – Arrays that exceed 75% will receive a secondary voltage rise analysis
L322: •  Typically permission to install is received within 5 business days of
L323: application submission
L324: 
L325: 
L326:  Applications that do not qualify or are between 25kW and 50kW
L327: will receive a full review by multiple engineering groups
L328: •  Typically permission to install will be received within 10-15 business
L329: days of application submission
L330: 
L331: 
L332: 10
L333: 
L334: Engineering Pre-screens
L335:  Required for systems between 50-250 kW
L336:  Option 1: Determine distance from substation radial or lateral
L337: connection and voltage level
L338: •  Main radial connections typically have larger wires allowing
L339: systems further away to interconnect without problems
L340: •  Higher tolerance for larger voltage levels (25 kV vs 12 kV) 
L341:  Option 2: Calculate impedance at point of interconnection (POI) 
L342:  Failed Pre-screen
L343: •  Distance from substation and size of system are not in the allowable
L344: range to pass the pre-screen or impedance is too high
L345: •  Screen is required 
L346: •  Operating requirements must be signed by customer (not required 
L347: if application passes pre-screen) 
L348: •  Projects that fail pre-screen or present additional issues for study
L349: may require additional time for issuance of permission to 
L350: install. 
L351: 11 
L352: February 1 2016
L353: 
L354: Engineering Screens
L355:  Required for systems > 250 kW or failed the pre-screen
L356:  High level power flow analysis required
L357:  Screening Criteria
L358: •  Voltage fluctuation is not greater than 2% at the POI or half the
L359: deadband at any capacitor or regulator
L360: •  Reverse power-generation does not exceed 80% of the daytime
L361: minimum load at voltage regulators feeder terminals and/or
L362: substation transformer without proper mitigation
L363: •  DER does not cause high voltage anywhere on the circuit 
L364: 
L365: 
L366: 12 
L367: February 1 2016
L368: 
L369: Engineering Advanced Study
L370:  Required if application does not pass high level screening
L371: process (at maximum output) 
L372:  Time series power flow analysis required
L373:  AMI data is used to gather customer specific load data 
L374:  Same criteria as screening procedure
L375:  Different types of advanced studies include: 
L376: •  Phase balancing
L377: •  Capacitor controls
L378: •  Lowering load tap changer (LTC) voltage
L379: •  Distribution Automation Operation
L380: 
L381: 
L382: 13 
L383: February 1 2016

L385: Existing Distribution Circuit Capacity Limits Guidelines
L386: 
L387: 
L388:  The aggregate limit of large (250 kW and over) generators
L389: running in parallel with a single existing distribution circuit is: 
L390: •  4 kV  0.5 MWs
L391: •  12 – 13.8 kV  3 MWs
L392: •  23 – 25 kV  6 MWs
L393: •  33.26 – 34.5 kV 10 MWs
L394: 
L395: 
L396:  After these limits are reached customers and developers can
L397: continue to request connection of systems less than 250 kW. 
L398: The circuit will continue to accommodate DER systems until
L399: voltage limits or other limits are reached
L400: 
L401: 
L402: 14 
L403: February 1 2016

L405: Express Circuit Capacity Limits for Radial Circuits
L406: 
L407: 
L408:  Distributed generation installations which exceed the limit for an existing
L409: radial circuit require an express circuit. The maximum generator size for
L410: express circuits is: 
L411: 
L412: 
L413: •  4 kV 
L414: •  12 – 13.8 kV 
L415: •  23 – 25 kV 
L416: •  33.26 – 34.5 kV 
L417: 
L418: 
L419: 0.5 MWs
L420: 10 MWs
L421: 10 MWs
L422: 15 MWs
L423: 
L424: 
L425:  The maximum length of an express feeder shall be 5 miles and must
L426: have demand and energy losses less than 3% 
L427: 
L428: 
L429: 15 
L430: February 1 2016
L431: 
L432: Distribution Power Transformer Limit
L433: 
L434: 
L435:  The aggregate limit of large (250 kW and over) generator
L436: injection to a single distribution transformer of 22.5 MVA
L437: nameplate or larger is 10 MWs. Transformers with nameplate
L438: ratings lower than 22.5 MVA may be given lower generation
L439: limits. 
L440: 
L441: 
L442:  We will consider adding a new transformer if there is no
L443: availability on any of the existing transformers and space is
L444: available in an existing substation. Any proposed transformers
L445: would be PHI’s standard distribution transformer (37 MVA
L446: nameplate rating). 
L447: 
L448: 
L449: 16 
L450: February 1 2016
L451: 
L452: Network Solutions 
L453: 
L454: 
L455:  Spot and Area Networks — for all DER systems over 50 kW to
L456: ensure that the proposed system output does not cause the network
L457: protector to operate the following control scheme is required: 
L458: •  Customer shall install a monitoring system on the service(s) to the facility
L459: and install inverters that can receive a control signal and curtail output to
L460: maintain the target level of import or export on each phase
L461: •  Customer system shall provide a web link and access to the utility to have
L462: read-only access to view the electrical parameters and operation of the
L463: system
L464: •  Customer system shall provide an alert to the utility via email or text
L465: message if the limit goes beyond a Company defined set point
L466: •  Customer monitoring system shall send a trip signal to the inverters if the
L467: limit goes beyond second Company determined set point and will send
L468: another alert to PHI 
L469: 
L470: 
L471: 17 
L472: February 1 2016
L473: 
L474: Synchronous Generation
L475: 
L476: 
L477:  Although synchronous generation must not cause high voltage or
L478: adverse impact on automatic line equipment there are several other
L479: criteria reviewed by Protection and Controls: 
L480:  Total short circuit current in relation to duty ratings of equipment
L481:  The ratio of generation to minimum load in a protected section must be
L482: less than 1/3
L483:  Coordination of fuses and reclosers must still function properly which
L484: includes overall reach of the protecting devices. 
L485:  These applications normally are processed in the same manner as a
L486: solar application but will normally require a more advanced
L487: engineering review.

L540:  Three-phase Unbalanced Circuit Model 
L541: •  Build circuit maps from GIS system and models are geospatial

L730: Application Processes
L731: Most utilities: 
L732: • Follow time constraints with applications
L733: • Have state mandates for applications

L742: Fast-Track Technical Screens
L743: Most utilities follow a version of FERC SGIP screens
L744: 
L745: 
L746: Some use minimum daytime load for penetration screen (prior
L747: to FERC SGIP 2013 order) 
L748: 
L749: 
L750: 1. Aggregated DG <15% of peak load on
L751: line section
L752: 2. For connection to a spot network: DG
L753: is inverter-based aggregated DG
L754: capacity is <5% of peak load & <50 kW
L755: 3. Aggregated DG contribution to
L756: maximum short circuit current is <10% 
L757: 4. Aggregated DG does not cause
L758: protective device to exceed 87.5% of
L759: short circuit interrupting capability 
L760: 
L761: 
L762: 5. DG interface is compatible with type of
L763: primary distribution line (wye/Delta) 
L764: 6. For a single-phase shared secondary 
L765: Aggregated DG capacity <20kW 
L766: 7. Resulting imbalance <20% of service
L767: transformer rating of 240 V service
L768: 8. Aggregated transmission connected DG
L769: capacity <10 MW for stability-limited
L770: area
L771: 9. Construction not required for
L772: interconnection

L904: Incorporating Energy Storage 
L905: 
L906: 
L907:  Multiple Configurations and Functions
L908: •  Behind the meter or direct connect
L909: •  Inverters shared or not shared with generation
L910: •  Two-way flow capability
L911: •  Participation in Ancillary Services Market
L912: •  Use for customer such as demand management premium power
L913:  Grid Interconnection
L914: •  The grid needs to be capable of accommodating the battery as a source or
L915: a load
L916:  Applicability of Net Energy Metering 
L917: •  Energy storage is not commonly viewed as a source of renewable
L918: generation
L919: •  Regulator must determine if energy storage meets requirements for NEM
L920: treatment
L921: •  If energy storage does meet requirements for NEM can the system be
L922: supplied from the grid or only from renewable generation? 
L923: 
L924: 
L925: 48 
L926: February 1 2016
L927: 
L928: Incorporating Energy Storage (Cont’d) 
L929: 
L930: 
L931:  Renewable Energy Credits
L932: •  Credit cannot be given for energy discharged from the battery that was
L933: originally sourced by the grid. 
L934: •  Appropriate metering is required. 
L935:  Technical and Operational Challenges
L936: •  Operating characteristics may have different impacts on the grid
L937: •  Degradation over time
L938: •  Planned use of system may change
L939: 
L940: 
L941: 49 
L942: February 1 2016
L943: 
L944: Evaluating the Impact of Energy Storage
L945: 
L946: 
L947:  The evaluation follows a similar review/screening/study process as
L948: DER generation based on size with a few added items: 
L949: 
L950: 
L951: •  If the energy storage system shares an inverter with the generation such as a
L952: PV system then the maximum power flow fluctuation would be the import to
L953: export range of the inverter. For example a 10 kW inverter system that can
L954: import or export 10 kW will be evaluated for the scenario where the power flow
L955: may fluctuate by 20 kW. 
L956: 
L957: 
L958: •  If the energy storage has a separate inverter from the generator such as PV 
L959: then the aggregate impact of the power flow fluctuation of the battery and
L960: generation will be evaluated. 
L961: 
L962: 
L963: •  If there are multiple energy storage systems on a feeder that will be used for
L964: frequency regulation (FR) then the aggregate will be studied as acting
L965: simultaneously. PHI may require different time delays for systems responding
L966: to regional transmission operator (RTO) FR signals. 
L967: 
L968: 
L969: •  If a battery can only be used for back up purposes then it will only be
L970: evaluated as a load.

L975: Questions/Comments
L976: 
L977: 
L978: 51
L979: 
L980: Accounting for Distributed Energy Energy Efficiency and Demand
L981: Response in the Distribution Planning Process
L982: 
L983: 
L984: Presented by Don Hall Manager Capacity Planning
L985: 
L986: 
L987: 52 
L988: April 7 2016
L989: 
L990: Distribution Planning – Mission 
L991: 
L992: 
L993:  The Mission of Distribution System Planning at PHI is to provide for
L994: the safe reliable economic and orderly modification and expansion of
L995: the utility electric distribution system to meet existing and future
L996: customer demands in a reliable manner. This may include adding
L997: equipment and facilities to increase capacity shifting or reconfiguring
L998: load among circuits or reconductoring circuits among other
L999: alternatives. 
L1000: •  Pepco Holdings companies maintain engineering and operating criteria
L1001: used in the design of new and modified portions of the distribution system. 
L1002: These criteria govern how: 
L1003: – Load carrying capacity of system facilities are determined and utilized
L1004: – Required service voltage levels are maintained
L1005:  Increasingly planning has required improved processes for evaluating
L1006: the future impacts of resources which may lead to reduction in load
L1007: and demand. 
L1008: 
L1009: 
L1010: 53
L1011: 
L1012: Justification for Enhancing the Planning Process 
L1013: 
L1014: 
L1015: PHI has proactively improved the distribution planning process
L1016: towards a more integrated system planning approach for several
L1017: reasons: 
L1018: •  Increasing penetrations of resources which may impact load and
L1019: peak demand are being added which include: 
L1020: •  Solar PV
L1021: •  Energy Efficiency
L1022: •  Demand Response and Direct Load Control
L1023: •  Greater transparency and justification for capital projects (or
L1024: deferral) 
L1025: •  Consider regulatory mandates which have been implemented in
L1026: other states (e.g. investment in non-wires alternatives) and ensure
L1027: the planning process has a framework in place to evaluate the
L1028: impact of these alternatives as appropriate
L1029: 
L1030: 
L1031: 54  54
L1032: 
L1033: Effects and Benefits of the Addition of Behind-the-meter
L1034: Generation
L1035: In addition to ongoing improvements PHI has also implemented several enhancements which
L1036: specifically address the Company’s Merger Commitment which states PHI must: 
L1037: 
L1038: 
L1039: “…include an analysis of the long term effects/benefits of the addition of behind-the-
L1040: meter distributed generation attached to the distribution system within its service
L1041: territory including any impacts on reliability and efficiency. PHI will also work with
L1042: PJM to evaluate any impacts that the growth in these resources may have on the
L1043: stability of the distribution system. 
L1044: 
L1045: 
L1046: Reliability
L1047: •  Assessed during the interconnection
L1048: process including (where necessary) the
L1049: generation profile of the resource relative to
L1050: load/demand so that no detrimental impacts
L1051: are introduced to the system or other
L1052: customers. 
L1053: 
L1054: 
L1055: •  PHI also considers the impact of distributed
L1056: generation on distribution automation (DA) 
L1057: schemes. In instances where DER may
L1058: impact DA schemes the company will make
L1059: reasonable investments to mitigate the
L1060: impact. 
L1061: 
L1062: 
L1063: Efficiency
L1064: •  PHI has historically considered the impact of
L1065: distributed energy resources in the planning
L1066: process when the aggregate amount of PV on a
L1067: circuit exceeded 1 MVA. 
L1068: • Impacts from distributed solar were applied to the
L1069: peak demand using a 22% capacity factor. 
L1070: 
L1071: 
L1072: •  PJM takes into consideration forecasted levels
L1073: of DER in its ten year load forecast. 
L1074: 
L1075: 
L1076: •  Additionally PHI now considers forecasted
L1077: levels of DER and any corresponding impacts
L1078: they may have on future load growth and
L1079: operation of the system when developing on
L1080: construction recommendations. 
L1081: 
L1082: 
L1083: 55 
L1084: 
L1085: Distribution System Planning - Process
L1086: 
L1087: 
L1088: The planning process is composed of short-term and long-term plans. 
L1089: 1. Biennial plans for each feeder in the utility service territory are
L1090: developed
L1091: •  Short-term plans include individual area load forecasts and detailed
L1092: engineering analyses to identify any near-term (i.e. over next three years) 
L1093: violations of the planning criteria
L1094: – Actions to mitigate any violations are developed and issued as construction
L1095: recommendations and result in capital and/or O&M projects
L1096: 2. A ten-year plan for the entire service territory is developed every
L1097: year
L1098: •  Long-term plans include a roll up of the most recent short-term plans 
L1099: extension of the short-term load forecasts to encompass a ten-year horizon 
L1100: and higher-level engineering analyses to identify potential violations of the
L1101: planning criteria (typically over the ten-year horizon to identify large
L1102: construction projects that require more than two-years lead time) 
L1103: – Actions to mitigate any violations are developed and result in potential capital projects 
L1104: in addition to those identified in the short-term plan
L1105: 
L1106: 
L1107: Annually these plans are reviewed to evaluate actual and projected loads and to make
L1108: adjustments that could be impacted by changes in commercial construction programs 
L1109: energy efficiency DER growth or other new technologies such as electric vehicles (EVs).
L1110: 
L1111: 
L1112: 56
L1113: 
L1114: Short Term Load Forecasting – Process
L1115: 
L1116: 
L1117:  Short term planning begins with historical analysis of the
L1118: peak load periods from the previous year
L1119: •  Each substation substation transformer and feeder is analyzed
L1120: – Actual loadings are obtained through PHI’s EMS or through field
L1121: measurements
L1122: – Loadings are analyzed to develop a base history reflective of peak
L1123: loadings during extreme (90/10) weather conditions for use in
L1124: forecasting future facility loadings
L1125:  Small area load forecasts are developed using Prospective
L1126: New Business (PNB) information
L1127: •  PNBs are found through utility applications for service and through
L1128: media developer and government reports on new construction
L1129: •  Planners predict loading and timing from the customer/developer
L1130: provided information plus media reports and site visits
L1131: •  Effects of known pending DERs are incorporated recognizing the
L1132: typical output level coincident with distribution system facility peak
L1133: loadings 
L1134: 
L1135: 
L1136: 57
L1137: 
L1138: Comparing PJM and PHI’s Forecasts
L1139: 
L1140: 
L1141:  While PHI and PJM’s load forecasts correspond as far as projected
L1142: load growth planning for PHI’s distribution system requires assessing
L1143: the Non-coincident peaks for each piece of equipment circuit and
L1144: substation. 
L1145:  Conversely PJM’s forecast is the sum of the Coincident Peaks 
L1146: across load zones. 
L1147:  PHI must plan to the Non-coincident peaks to ensure each component
L1148: of the distribution system is not overloaded beyond its normal and
L1149: emergency ratings.

L1402: How Circuit-Level Impacts are Assessed
L1403: •  To determine whether a resource
L1404: will impact PHI’s load forecast and
L1405: corresponding construction
L1406: recommendations several pieces
L1407: of information are required
L1408: •  The normal capacity rating of the
L1409: circuit (MVA) 
L1410: •  The emergency rating of the circuit
L1411: (MVA) 
L1412: •  The types size and quantity of load-
L1413: modifying resources on the
L1414: corresponding circuit
L1415: 
L1416: 
L1417: •  Calculating the impact of each resource
L1418: requires accounting for circuit specific
L1419: attributes as well as the characteristics
L1420: of the resource itself
L1421: •  It is important to note that while PHI has
L1422: direct control over some programs (e.g. 
L1423: DLC CVR) other programs (e.g. 
L1424: PESC EMT) depend on customer
L1425: behavior. 
L1426:

L1430: •  Availability
L1431: •  Generation Profile

L1448: 
L1449: Accounting for Impacts in the Planning Process 
L1450: 
L1451: 
L1452: •  As a sensitivity analysis effects of forecasted and installed DER 
L1453: Direct Load Control and Peak Energy Savings Credit programs are
L1454: removed from the predicted feeder/transformer/substation loadings
L1455: (i.e. added back in) 
L1456: 
L1457: 
L1458: •  Those adjusted loads are compared to the emergency capacity of the
L1459: feeder and transformer and the firm capacity of the substation. 
L1460: 
L1461: 
L1462: •  The effects of each of the aforementioned programs/resources will be
L1463: calculated/derived by feeder where appropriate. When effects can
L1464: only be calculated or derived by substation the effects will be
L1465: allocated to each feeder served by that substation based upon the
L1466: ratio of feeder load versus total feeder load. 
L1467: 
L1468: 
L1469: •  The impacts of adding these resources back in will be evaluated and
L1470: may trigger different recommendations at each level of the system
L1471: (e.g. load transfer w/o PV may require different actions at the feeder
L1472: level vs. at the substation level) 
L1473:

L107: committed to improved and enhanced facilitation of the interconnection of

L255: 
L256: Overview of Revised Technical Analysis
L257: 
L258: 
L259:  PHI’s criteria limits are designed to identify the potential for detrimental
L260: technical conditions that impact the power quality at the customer level
L261: and/or the reliability of the distribution system: 
L262:  High- and low-voltage conditions
L263:  Voltage fluctuations
L264:  Frequency deviations
L265:  Harmonic distortions
L266:  Overcurrent (Overload & Excessive Fault Current) 
L267:  Excessive impacts on the reliable service life of regulating equipment
L268:  Reactive power issues – power factor variations
L269:  Reverse power flow on equipment not designed for it
L270:  Protection and coordination issues
L271:  Impacts on the transmission system
L272:  Impacts on other customers 
L273:

L276: 
L277: Levels of Engineering Review of Interconnection
L278: Applications
L279: 
L280: 
L281: Small Application
L282: Review 
L283: 
L284: 
L285: Pre-screen 
L286: 
L287: 
L288: Screen
L289: 
L290: 
L291: Advanced Study 
L292: 
L293: 
L294: •  PHI utilizes a hierarchal
L295: screening process
L296: •  An application will require
L297: more thorough and
L298: comprehensive analysis only
L299: if it fails to pass a simpler
L300: screen first. 
L301: •  Process is consistent with the
L302: FERC Small Generator
L303: Interconnection Procedures
L304: (SGIP) 
L305: 
L306: 
L307: 9 
L308: February 1 2016
L309: 
L310: Small System Application Review (50kW and below) 
L311: 
L312: 
L313:  An expedited process for systems 10 kW and below has 
L314: significantly improved response time and that process will be
L315: extended to 25 kW systems starting in September 2016
L316:  Applications 25kW and below qualify for expedited review if they
L317: meet the following conditions: 
L318: •  Not currently served by a restricted or network feeder
L319: •  Inverter is IEEE/UL certified
L320: •  Total kW of PV Array(s) does not exceed the transformer rating
L321: – Arrays that exceed 75% will receive a secondary voltage rise analysis
L322: •  Typically permission to install is received within 5 business days of
L323: application submission
L324: 
L325: 
L326:  Applications that do not qualify or are between 25kW and 50kW
L327: will receive a full review by multiple engineering groups
L328: •  Typically permission to install will be received within 10-15 business
L329: days of application submission
L330: 
L331: 
L332: 10
L333: 
L334: Engineering Pre-screens
L335:  Required for systems between 50-250 kW
L336:  Option 1: Determine distance from substation radial or lateral
L337: connection and voltage level
L338: •  Main radial connections typically have larger wires allowing
L339: systems further away to interconnect without problems
L340: •  Higher tolerance for larger voltage levels (25 kV vs 12 kV) 
L341:  Option 2: Calculate impedance at point of interconnection (POI) 
L342:  Failed Pre-screen
L343: •  Distance from substation and size of system are not in the allowable
L344: range to pass the pre-screen or impedance is too high
L345: •  Screen is required 
L346: •  Operating requirements must be signed by customer (not required 
L347: if application passes pre-screen) 
L348: •  Projects that fail pre-screen or present additional issues for study
L349: may require additional time for issuance of permission to 
L350: install. 
L351: 11 
L352: February 1 2016
L353: 
L354: Engineering Screens
L355:  Required for systems > 250 kW or failed the pre-screen
L356:  High level power flow analysis required
L357:  Screening Criteria
L358: •  Voltage fluctuation is not greater than 2% at the POI or half the
L359: deadband at any capacitor or regulator
L360: •  Reverse power-generation does not exceed 80% of the daytime
L361: minimum load at voltage regulators feeder terminals and/or
L362: substation transformer without proper mitigation
L363: •  DER does not cause high voltage anywhere on the circuit 
L364: 
L365: 
L366: 12 
L367: February 1 2016
L368: 
L369: Engineering Advanced Study
L370:  Required if application does not pass high level screening
L371: process (at maximum output) 
L372:  Time series power flow analysis required
L373:  AMI data is used to gather customer specific load data 
L374:  Same criteria as screening procedure
L375:  Different types of advanced studies include: 
L376: •  Phase balancing
L377: •  Capacitor controls
L378: •  Lowering load tap changer (LTC) voltage
L379: •  Distribution Automation Operation
L380: 
L381: 
L382: 13 
L383: February 1 2016
L384: 
L385: Existing Distribution Circuit Capacity Limits Guidelines
L386: 
L387: 
L388:  The aggregate limit of large (250 kW and over) generators
L389: running in parallel with a single existing distribution circuit is: 
L390: •  4 kV  0.5 MWs
L391: •  12 – 13.8 kV  3 MWs
L392: •  23 – 25 kV  6 MWs
L393: •  33.26 – 34.5 kV 10 MWs
L394: 
L395: 
L396:  After these limits are reached customers and developers can
L397: continue to request connection of systems less than 250 kW. 
L398: The circuit will continue to accommodate DER systems until
L399: voltage limits or other limits are reached
L400: 
L401: 
L402: 14 
L403: February 1 2016
L404: 
L405: Express Circuit Capacity Limits for Radial Circuits
L406: 
L407: 
L408:  Distributed generation installations which exceed the limit for an existing
L409: radial circuit require an express circuit. The maximum generator size for
L410: express circuits is: 
L411: 
L412: 
L413: •  4 kV 
L414: •  12 – 13.8 kV 
L415: •  23 – 25 kV 
L416: •  33.26 – 34.5 kV 
L417: 
L418: 
L419: 0.5 MWs
L420: 10 MWs
L421: 10 MWs
L422: 15 MWs
L423: 
L424: 
L425:  The maximum length of an express feeder shall be 5 miles and must
L426: have demand and energy losses less than 3% 
L427: 
L428: 
L429: 15 
L430: February 1 2016
L431: 
L432: Distribution Power Transformer Limit
L433: 
L434: 
L435:  The aggregate limit of large (250 kW and over) generator
L436: injection to a single distribution transformer of 22.5 MVA
L437: nameplate or larger is 10 MWs. Transformers with nameplate
L438: ratings lower than 22.5 MVA may be given lower generation
L439: limits. 
L440: 
L441: 
L442:  We will consider adding a new transformer if there is no
L443: availability on any of the existing transformers and space is
L444: available in an existing substation. Any proposed transformers
L445: would be PHI’s standard distribution transformer (37 MVA
L446: nameplate rating). 
L447: 
L448: 
L449: 16 
L450: February 1 2016
L451: 
L452: Network Solutions 
L453: 
L454: 
L455:  Spot and Area Networks — for all DER systems over 50 kW to
L456: ensure that the proposed system output does not cause the network
L457: protector to operate the following control scheme is required: 
L458: •  Customer shall install a monitoring system on the service(s) to the facility
L459: and install inverters that can receive a control signal and curtail output to
L460: maintain the target level of import or export on each phase
L461: •  Customer system shall provide a web link and access to the utility to have
L462: read-only access to view the electrical parameters and operation of the
L463: system
L464: •  Customer system shall provide an alert to the utility via email or text
L465: message if the limit goes beyond a Company defined set point
L466: •  Customer monitoring system shall send a trip signal to the inverters if the
L467: limit goes beyond second Company determined set point and will send
L468: another alert to PHI 
L469: 
L470: 
L471: 17 
L472: February 1 2016
L473: 
L474: Synchronous Generation
L475: 
L476: 
L477:  Although synchronous generation must not cause high voltage or
L478: adverse impact on automatic line equipment there are several other
L479: criteria reviewed by Protection and Controls: 
L480:  Total short circuit current in relation to duty ratings of equipment
L481:  The ratio of generation to minimum load in a protected section must be
L482: less than 1/3
L483:  Coordination of fuses and reclosers must still function properly which
L484: includes overall reach of the protecting devices. 
L485:  These applications normally are processed in the same manner as a
L486: solar application but will normally require a more advanced
L487: engineering review.

L507: 
L508: 
L509: •  The need to do detailed time series studies for the
L510: interconnection of DER 
L511: 
L512: 
L513: •  The ability to assess aggregate impact of DER continuing
L514: impact on the PHI electrical grid
L515: 
L516: 
L517: •  The need to quickly screen whether PV adoption will cause a
L518: violation
L519: 
L520: 
L521: •  The ability to assess the hosting capacity of radial distribution
L522: circuits or the secondary network
L523: 
L524: 
L525: •  The ability to model smart inverters along with other new types

L527: 
L528:

L530: each feeder

L535: Advanced Modeling Software and Data
L536: 
L537: 
L538:  Distribution Engineering Workstation (DEW) – Software used to 
L539: perform modeling and analysis
L540:  Three-phase Unbalanced Circuit Model 
L541: •  Build circuit maps from GIS system and models are geospatial
L542: •  Simulates the movement of Voltage Regulators Capacitors etc. 
L543: •  Automatically maps all DERs to the correct location in the model
L544: •  Brings in hourly load – customer load and SCADA
L545: •  Interfaces and brings in historical irradiance for the specific location
L546:  Time Series Analysis 
L547: •  Hourly interval is standard 
L548: •  Finds the critical points looking at all hours of year
L549:  Measurement data (time synchronized) 
L550: •  Start of circuit (SCADA) 
L551: •  Customer load data (from AMI or profiled consumption data) 
L552: •  Generation measurements 
L553: 
L554: 
L555: 22
L556: 
L557: DEW’s Advanced Modeling Tools to Complete High-
L558: Penetration PV Integration Studies
L559:  Generation Time Series Analysis 
L560: •  Determines the most critical time points for analysis by analyzing all intervals
L561: Minimum Daytime Load (MDL) Max Load Point Low Load Point
L562: Max PV Point Max PV/Load Ratio Max Difference Point
L563: •  Movement of utility control equipment
L564: 
L565: 
L566:  Generation Impact Analysis (Hourly data for critical days) 
L567: •  Detail Studies covering the periods of worst case circuit conditions
L568: •  Analyze the loss and return of generation with and without regulation 
L569: •  Analyze PV power factor settings if needed
L570: 
L571: 
L572:  Generation Fault Analysis
L573: •  Screening & fault studies 
L574:

L730: Application Processes
L731: Most utilities: 
L732: • Follow time constraints with applications
L733: • Have state mandates for applications
L734: • Have multiple tier applications
L735: • Have an inverter-based PV application
L736: • Interconnection applications are
L737: available online 
L738: 
L739: 
L740: 38
L741: 
L742: Fast-Track Technical Screens
L743: Most utilities follow a version of FERC SGIP screens
L744: 
L745: 
L746: Some use minimum daytime load for penetration screen (prior
L747: to FERC SGIP 2013 order) 
L748: 
L749: 
L750: 1. Aggregated DG <15% of peak load on
L751: line section
L752: 2. For connection to a spot network: DG
L753: is inverter-based aggregated DG
L754: capacity is <5% of peak load & <50 kW
L755: 3. Aggregated DG contribution to
L756: maximum short circuit current is <10% 
L757: 4. Aggregated DG does not cause
L758: protective device to exceed 87.5% of
L759: short circuit interrupting capability 
L760: 
L761: 
L762: 5. DG interface is compatible with type of
L763: primary distribution line (wye/Delta) 
L764: 6. For a single-phase shared secondary 
L765: Aggregated DG capacity <20kW 
L766: 7. Resulting imbalance <20% of service
L767: transformer rating of 240 V service
L768: 8. Aggregated transmission connected DG
L769: capacity <10 MW for stability-limited
L770: area
L771: 9. Construction not required for
L772: interconnection 
L773: 
L774:

L777: Supplemental Screening
L778: 
L779: 
L780: • Used to pass some interconnection applications
L781: when fast-track screens are failed (e.g. replace
L782: service transformer secondary loop) 
L783: • Typically quick and inexpensive solutions rather
L784: than conducting a detailed impact study
L785: • Implemented only by some utilities
L786: • Now part of the FERC SGIP

L904: Incorporating Energy Storage 
L905: 
L906: 
L907:  Multiple Configurations and Functions
L908: •  Behind the meter or direct connect
L909: •  Inverters shared or not shared with generation
L910: •  Two-way flow capability
L911: •  Participation in Ancillary Services Market
L912: •  Use for customer such as demand management premium power
L913:  Grid Interconnection
L914: •  The grid needs to be capable of accommodating the battery as a source or
L915: a load
L916:  Applicability of Net Energy Metering 
L917: •  Energy storage is not commonly viewed as a source of renewable
L918: generation
L919: •  Regulator must determine if energy storage meets requirements for NEM
L920: treatment
L921: •  If energy storage does meet requirements for NEM can the system be
L922: supplied from the grid or only from renewable generation? 
L923: 
L924: 
L925: 48 
L926: February 1 2016
L927: 
L928: Incorporating Energy Storage (Cont’d) 
L929: 
L930: 
L931:  Renewable Energy Credits
L932: •  Credit cannot be given for energy discharged from the battery that was
L933: originally sourced by the grid. 
L934: •  Appropriate metering is required. 
L935:  Technical and Operational Challenges
L936: •  Operating characteristics may have different impacts on the grid
L937: •  Degradation over time
L938: •  Planned use of system may change

L944: Evaluating the Impact of Energy Storage
L945: 
L946: 
L947:  The evaluation follows a similar review/screening/study process as
L948: DER generation based on size with a few added items: 
L949: 
L950: 
L951: •  If the energy storage system shares an inverter with the generation such as a
L952: PV system then the maximum power flow fluctuation would be the import to
L953: export range of the inverter. For example a 10 kW inverter system that can
L954: import or export 10 kW will be evaluated for the scenario where the power flow
L955: may fluctuate by 20 kW. 
L956: 
L957: 
L958: •  If the energy storage has a separate inverter from the generator such as PV 
L959: then the aggregate impact of the power flow fluctuation of the battery and
L960: generation will be evaluated. 
L961: 
L962: 
L963: •  If there are multiple energy storage systems on a feeder that will be used for
L964: frequency regulation (FR) then the aggregate will be studied as acting
L965: simultaneously. PHI may require different time delays for systems responding
L966: to regional transmission operator (RTO) FR signals. 
L967: 
L968: 
L969: •  If a battery can only be used for back up purposes then it will only be
L970: evaluated as a load.

L990: Distribution Planning – Mission 
L991: 
L992: 
L993:  The Mission of Distribution System Planning at PHI is to provide for
L994: the safe reliable economic and orderly modification and expansion of
L995: the utility electric distribution system to meet existing and future
L996: customer demands in a reliable manner. This may include adding
L997: equipment and facilities to increase capacity shifting or reconfiguring
L998: load among circuits or reconductoring circuits among other
L999: alternatives. 
L1000: •  Pepco Holdings companies maintain engineering and operating criteria
L1001: used in the design of new and modified portions of the distribution system. 
L1002: These criteria govern how: 
L1003: – Load carrying capacity of system facilities are determined and utilized
L1004: – Required service voltage levels are maintained
L1005:  Increasingly planning has required improved processes for evaluating
L1006: the future impacts of resources which may lead to reduction in load
L1007: and demand. 
L1008: 
L1009: 
L1010: 53
L1011: 
L1012: Justification for Enhancing the Planning Process 
L1013: 
L1014: 
L1015: PHI has proactively improved the distribution planning process
L1016: towards a more integrated system planning approach for several
L1017: reasons: 
L1018: •  Increasing penetrations of resources which may impact load and
L1019: peak demand are being added which include: 
L1020: •  Solar PV
L1021: •  Energy Efficiency
L1022: •  Demand Response and Direct Load Control
L1023: •  Greater transparency and justification for capital projects (or
L1024: deferral) 
L1025: •  Consider regulatory mandates which have been implemented in
L1026: other states (e.g. investment in non-wires alternatives) and ensure
L1027: the planning process has a framework in place to evaluate the
L1028: impact of these alternatives as appropriate
L1029: 
L1030: 
L1031: 54  54
L1032: 
L1033: Effects and Benefits of the Addition of Behind-the-meter
L1034: Generation
L1035: In addition to ongoing improvements PHI has also implemented several enhancements which
L1036: specifically address the Company’s Merger Commitment which states PHI must: 
L1037: 
L1038: 
L1039: “…include an analysis of the long term effects/benefits of the addition of behind-the-
L1040: meter distributed generation attached to the distribution system within its service
L1041: territory including any impacts on reliability and efficiency. PHI will also work with
L1042: PJM to evaluate any impacts that the growth in these resources may have on the
L1043: stability of the distribution system. 
L1044: 
L1045: 
L1046: Reliability
L1047: •  Assessed during the interconnection
L1048: process including (where necessary) the
L1049: generation profile of the resource relative to
L1050: load/demand so that no detrimental impacts
L1051: are introduced to the system or other
L1052: customers. 
L1053: 
L1054: 
L1055: •  PHI also considers the impact of distributed
L1056: generation on distribution automation (DA) 
L1057: schemes. In instances where DER may
L1058: impact DA schemes the company will make
L1059: reasonable investments to mitigate the
L1060: impact. 
L1061: 
L1062: 
L1063: Efficiency
L1064: •  PHI has historically considered the impact of
L1065: distributed energy resources in the planning
L1066: process when the aggregate amount of PV on a
L1067: circuit exceeded 1 MVA. 
L1068: • Impacts from distributed solar were applied to the
L1069: peak demand using a 22% capacity factor. 
L1070: 
L1071: 
L1072: •  PJM takes into consideration forecasted levels
L1073: of DER in its ten year load forecast. 
L1074: 
L1075: 
L1076: •  Additionally PHI now considers forecasted
L1077: levels of DER and any corresponding impacts
L1078: they may have on future load growth and
L1079: operation of the system when developing on
L1080: construction recommendations. 
L1081: 
L1082: 
L1083: 55 
L1084: 
L1085: Distribution System Planning - Process
L1086: 
L1087: 
L1088: The planning process is composed of short-term and long-term plans. 
L1089: 1. Biennial plans for each feeder in the utility service territory are
L1090: developed
L1091: •  Short-term plans include individual area load forecasts and detailed
L1092: engineering analyses to identify any near-term (i.e. over next three years) 
L1093: violations of the planning criteria
L1094: – Actions to mitigate any violations are developed and issued as construction
L1095: recommendations and result in capital and/or O&M projects
L1096: 2. A ten-year plan for the entire service territory is developed every
L1097: year
L1098: •  Long-term plans include a roll up of the most recent short-term plans 
L1099: extension of the short-term load forecasts to encompass a ten-year horizon 
L1100: and higher-level engineering analyses to identify potential violations of the
L1101: planning criteria (typically over the ten-year horizon to identify large
L1102: construction projects that require more than two-years lead time) 
L1103: – Actions to mitigate any violations are developed and result in potential capital projects 
L1104: in addition to those identified in the short-term plan
L1105: 
L1106: 
L1107: Annually these plans are reviewed to evaluate actual and projected loads and to make
L1108: adjustments that could be impacted by changes in commercial construction programs 
L1109: energy efficiency DER growth or other new technologies such as electric vehicles (EVs).
L1110: 
L1111: 
L1112: 56
L1113: 
L1114: Short Term Load Forecasting – Process
L1115: 
L1116: 
L1117:  Short term planning begins with historical analysis of the
L1118: peak load periods from the previous year
L1119: •  Each substation substation transformer and feeder is analyzed
L1120: – Actual loadings are obtained through PHI’s EMS or through field
L1121: measurements
L1122: – Loadings are analyzed to develop a base history reflective of peak
L1123: loadings during extreme (90/10) weather conditions for use in
L1124: forecasting future facility loadings
L1125:  Small area load forecasts are developed using Prospective
L1126: New Business (PNB) information
L1127: •  PNBs are found through utility applications for service and through
L1128: media developer and government reports on new construction
L1129: •  Planners predict loading and timing from the customer/developer
L1130: provided information plus media reports and site visits
L1131: •  Effects of known pending DERs are incorporated recognizing the
L1132: typical output level coincident with distribution system facility peak
L1133: loadings 
L1134: 
L1135: 
L1136: 57
L1137: 
L1138: Comparing PJM and PHI’s Forecasts
L1139: 
L1140: 
L1141:  While PHI and PJM’s load forecasts correspond as far as projected
L1142: load growth planning for PHI’s distribution system requires assessing
L1143: the Non-coincident peaks for each piece of equipment circuit and
L1144: substation. 
L1145:  Conversely PJM’s forecast is the sum of the Coincident Peaks 
L1146: across load zones. 
L1147:  PHI must plan to the Non-coincident peaks to ensure each component
L1148: of the distribution system is not overloaded beyond its normal and
L1149: emergency ratings.

L1402: How Circuit-Level Impacts are Assessed
L1403: •  To determine whether a resource
L1404: will impact PHI’s load forecast and
L1405: corresponding construction
L1406: recommendations several pieces
L1407: of information are required
L1408: •  The normal capacity rating of the
L1409: circuit (MVA) 
L1410: •  The emergency rating of the circuit
L1411: (MVA) 
L1412: •  The types size and quantity of load-
L1413: modifying resources on the
L1414: corresponding circuit
L1415: 
L1416: 
L1417: •  Calculating the impact of each resource
L1418: requires accounting for circuit specific
L1419: attributes as well as the characteristics
L1420: of the resource itself
L1421: •  It is important to note that while PHI has
L1422: direct control over some programs (e.g. 
L1423: DLC CVR) other programs (e.g. 
L1424: PESC EMT) depend on customer
L1425: behavior.

L1449: Accounting for Impacts in the Planning Process 
L1450: 
L1451: 
L1452: •  As a sensitivity analysis effects of forecasted and installed DER 
L1453: Direct Load Control and Peak Energy Savings Credit programs are
L1454: removed from the predicted feeder/transformer/substation loadings
L1455: (i.e. added back in) 
L1456: 
L1457: 
L1458: •  Those adjusted loads are compared to the emergency capacity of the
L1459: feeder and transformer and the firm capacity of the substation. 
L1460: 
L1461: 
L1462: •  The effects of each of the aforementioned programs/resources will be
L1463: calculated/derived by feeder where appropriate. When effects can
L1464: only be calculated or derived by substation the effects will be
L1465: allocated to each feeder served by that substation based upon the
L1466: ratio of feeder load versus total feeder load. 
L1467: 
L1468: 
L1469: •  The impacts of adding these resources back in will be evaluated and
L1470: may trigger different recommendations at each level of the system
L1471: (e.g. load transfer w/o PV may require different actions at the feeder
L1472: level vs. at the substation level)

 PHI’s criteria limits are designed to identify the potential for detrimental
technical conditions that impact the power quality at the customer level
and/or the reliability of the distribution system: 
 High- and low-voltage conditions
 Voltage fluctuations
 Frequency deviations
 Harmonic distortions
 Overcurrent (Overload & Excessive Fault Current) 
 Excessive impacts on the reliable service life of regulating equipment
 Reactive power issues – power factor variations
 Reverse power flow on equipment not designed for it
 Protection and coordination issues
 Impacts on the transmission system
 Impacts on other customers

content.text:
Small System Application Review (50kW and below) 


 An expedited process for systems 10 kW and below has 
significantly improved response time and that process will be
extended to 25 kW systems starting in September 2016
 Applications 25kW and below qualify for expedited review if they
meet the following conditions: 
•  Not currently served by a restricted or network feeder
•  Inverter is IEEE/UL certified
•  Total kW of PV Array(s) does not exceed the transformer rating
– Arrays that exceed 75% will receive a secondary voltage rise analysis
•  Typically permission to install is received within 5 business days of
application submission


 Applications that do not qualify or are between 25kW and 50kW
will receive a full review by multiple engineering groups
•  Typically permission to install will be received within 10-15 business
days of application submission

content.text:
Engineering Screens
 Required for systems > 250 kW or failed the pre-screen
 High level power flow analysis required
 Screening Criteria
•  Voltage fluctuation is not greater than 2% at the POI or half the
deadband at any capacitor or regulator
•  Reverse power-generation does not exceed 80% of the daytime
minimum load at voltage regulators feeder terminals and/or
substation transformer without proper mitigation
•  DER does not cause high voltage anywhere on the circuit

Engineering Advanced Study
 Required if application does not pass high level screening
process (at maximum output) 
 Time series power flow analysis required
 AMI data is used to gather customer specific load data 
 Same criteria as screening procedure
 Different types of advanced studies include: 
•  Phase balancing
•  Capacitor controls
•  Lowering load tap changer (LTC) voltage
•  Distribution Automation Operation

content.text:
 The aggregate limit of large (250 kW and over) generators
running in parallel with a single existing distribution circuit is: 
•  4 kV  0.5 MWs
•  12 – 13.8 kV  3 MWs
•  23 – 25 kV  6 MWs
•  33.26 – 34.5 kV 10 MWs


 After these limits are reached customers and developers can
continue to request connection of systems less than 250 kW. 
The circuit will continue to accommodate DER systems until
voltage limits or other limits are reached

content.text:
 Spot and Area Networks — for all DER systems over 50 kW to
ensure that the proposed system output does not cause the network
protector to operate the following control scheme is required: 
•  Customer shall install a monitoring system on the service(s) to the facility
and install inverters that can receive a control signal and curtail output to
maintain the target level of import or export on each phase
•  Customer system shall provide a web link and access to the utility to have
read-only access to view the electrical parameters and operation of the
system
•  Customer system shall provide an alert to the utility via email or text
message if the limit goes beyond a Company defined set point
•  Customer monitoring system shall send a trip signal to the inverters if the
limit goes beyond second Company determined set point and will send
another alert to PHI

content.text:
 Although synchronous generation must not cause high voltage or
adverse impact on automatic line equipment there are several other
criteria reviewed by Protection and Controls: 
 Total short circuit current in relation to duty ratings of equipment
 The ratio of generation to minimum load in a protected section must be
less than 1/3
 Coordination of fuses and reclosers must still function properly which
includes overall reach of the protecting devices. 
 These applications normally are processed in the same manner as a
solar application but will normally require a more advanced
engineering review.

content.text:
 The evaluation follows a similar review/screening/study process as
DER generation based on size with a few added items: 


•  If the energy storage system shares an inverter with the generation such as a
PV system then the maximum power flow fluctuation would be the import to
export range of the inverter. For example a 10 kW inverter system that can
import or export 10 kW will be evaluated for the scenario where the power flow
may fluctuate by 20 kW. 


•  If the energy storage has a separate inverter from the generator such as PV 
then the aggregate impact of the power flow fluctuation of the battery and
generation will be evaluated. 


•  If there are multiple energy storage systems on a feeder that will be used for
frequency regulation (FR) then the aggregate will be studied as acting
simultaneously. PHI may require different time delays for systems responding
to regional transmission operator (RTO) FR signals. 


•  If a battery can only be used for back up purposes then it will only be
evaluated as a load.

DER generation based on size with a few added items: 


•  If the energy storage system shares an inverter with the generation such as a
PV system then the maximum power flow fluctuation would be the import to
export range of the inverter. For example a 10 kW inverter system that can
import or export 10 kW will be evaluated for the scenario where the power flow
may fluctuate by 20 kW. 


•  If the energy storage has a separate inverter from the generator such as PV 
then the aggregate impact of the power flow fluctuation of the battery and
generation will be evaluated. 


•  If there are multiple energy storage systems on a feeder that will be used for
frequency regulation (FR) then the aggregate will be studied as acting

evaluated as a load.

parts:
PEPCO's SCADA (Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition) requirements for Distributed Energy Resources (DER), as outlined in their stakeholder meeting presentation, include various technical and operational criteria:

1. **Technical Conditions and Criteria Limits**: These criteria are designed to prevent detrimental technical conditions that could impact power quality at the customer level or the reliability of the distribution system. They include managing high- and low-voltage conditions, voltage fluctuations, frequency deviations, harmonic distortions, overcurrent (overload and excessive fault current), impacts on the reliable service life of regulating equipment, reactive power issues (power factor variations), reverse power flow on equipment not designed for it, protection and coordination issues, impacts on the transmission system, and impacts on other customers【10†source】.

2. **Small System Application Review (50kW and Below)**: Systems 10 kW and below have an expedited review process, which is extended to 25 kW systems. For expedited review, the application must meet specific conditions such as not being served by a restricted or network feeder, having an IEEE/UL certified inverter, and the total kW of PV Arrays not exceeding the transformer rating. Applications that do not qualify for expedited review or are between 25kW and 50kW receive a full review by multiple engineering groups【11†source】.

3. **Engineering Screens for Systems Over 250 kW**: These screens require a high-level power flow analysis. The screening criteria include voltage fluctuation not exceeding specific limits, reverse power-generation not exceeding a certain percentage of the daytime minimum load, and ensuring DER does not cause high voltage anywhere on the circuit【12†source】.

4. **Engineering Advanced Study**: Required if the application does not pass the high-level screening process. It includes a time series power flow analysis and uses AMI data to gather customer-specific load data. Types of advanced studies include phase balancing, capacitor controls, lowering load tap changer voltage, and distribution automation operation【13†source】.

5. **Aggregate Limits for Large Generators**: There are specified limits for large (250 kW and over) generators running in parallel with a single existing distribution circuit. These limits vary based on the voltage level of the circuit【14†source】.

6. **Control Scheme for DER Systems Over 50 kW**: Systems over 50 kW must install a monitoring system and inverters that can receive a control signal to maintain the target level of import or export on each phase. The system must provide a web link for utility access, send alerts for defined limit breaches, and have a trip signal for inverters【15†source】.

7. **Criteria for Synchronous Generation**: Synchronous generation must not cause high voltage or adverse impact on automatic line equipment. Criteria include total short circuit current in relation to duty ratings of equipment, the ratio of generation to minimum load in a protected section, and coordination of fuses and reclosers【16†source】.

8. **Energy Storage Evaluation**: The evaluation of energy storage systems follows a similar review/screening/study process as DER generation but with additional considerations depending on whether the energy storage shares an inverter with the generation, has a separate inverter, is used for frequency regulation, or is used only for backup purposes【17†source】. 

These requirements highlight PEPCO's focus on maintaining system reliability and power quality while integrating DERs into the distribution system.

•  Customer shall install a monitoring system on the service(s) to the facility
and install inverters that can receive a control signal and curtail output to
maintain the target level of import or export on each phase
•  Customer system shall provide a web link and access to the utility to have
read-only access to view the electrical parameters and operation of the
system
•  Customer system shall provide an alert to the utility via email or text
message if the limit goes beyond a Company defined set point
•  Customer monitoring system shall send a trip signal to the inverters if the
limit goes beyond second Company determined set point and will send
another alert to PHI

content_references.name: Stakeholder Meeting Presentation - DER FINAL for 08.30.16 (1).pdf
content_references.snippet:
 Although synchronous generation must not cause high voltage or
adverse impact on automatic line equipment there are several other
criteria reviewed by Protection and Controls: 
 Total short circuit current in relation to duty ratings of equipment
 The ratio of generation to minimum load in a protected section must be
less than 1/3
 Coordination of fuses and reclosers must still function properly which
includes overall reach of the protecting devices. 
 These applications normally are processed in the same manner as a
solar application but will normally require a more advanced
engineering review.

content_references.name: Stakeholder Meeting Presentation - DER FINAL for 08.30.16 (1).pdf
content_references.snippet:
 The evaluation follows a similar review/screening/study process as
DER generation based on size with a few added items: 


•  If the energy storage system shares an inverter with the generation such as a
PV system then the maximum power flow fluctuation would be the import to
export range of the inverter. For example a 10 kW inverter system that can
import or export 10 kW will be evaluated for the scenario where the power flow
may fluctuate by 20 kW. 


•  If the energy storage has a separate inverter from the generator such as PV 
then the aggregate impact of the power flow fluctuation of the battery and
generation will be evaluated. 


•  If there are multiple energy storage systems on a feeder that will be used for
frequency regulation (FR) then the aggregate will be studied as acting
simultaneously. PHI may require different time delays for systems responding
to regional transmission operator (RTO) FR signals. 


•  If a battery can only be used for back up purposes then it will only be
evaluated as a load.
